Topic.Title: Blow out earnings - Here's Why

Message.Msg: IPhone sales started dropping off 2 weeks before Xmas. But Samsung sales dropped off when the iPhone 5 was released in September. So, did Samsung steal business from Apple? No. Both companies picked up customers new to smart phones. But Apple held onto their existing customer base and converted previous Android users (such as myself) to Apple. Remember, Apple only has 15% market share. Even if Apple splits sales with Samsung, their market share still goes up.

Message.Title: Apple's iOS retains top spot in US with over 51% share of smartphone OS sales for Q4 2012
Message.Msg: Accounting for over a 51% share of all smartphone OS sales in the U.S., Apple's iOS continues to be the market leader as existing customers move away from rival platforms like Android or upgrade older iPhones. According to data released by Kantar Worldpanel ComTech on Tuesday, iOS accounted for 51.2 percent of all U.S. smartphone OS sales for the 12-week period ending on Dec. 23, 2012, up over 7 percent from 44.9 percent in 2011. The market research group conducts more than 250,000 interviews per year in the U.S. to track mobile phone purchasing behavior, associated bills and other metrics. Apple's increased performance appears to be at the cost of Android as Google's mobile OS marketshare declined from 44.8 percent in quarter four 2011 to 44.2 percent over the same period in 2012. “In particular, 36% of iOS sales were derived from other smartphone users over the last year," said Kantar Worldpanel ComTech analyst Mary-Ann Parlato. "While this figure remains stable over time, the proportion of Android users moving towards the Apple brand increases. 19% of iOS sales over the last year were derived from Android users, compared to 9% in 2011."

Topic.Title: Apple's iOS retains top spot in US with over 51% share of smartphone OS sales for Q4 2012

Message.Title: Android phone sell is not equal to google profit. Zero $ in China
Message.Msg: But, but: Obviously, Google’s access to this data on non-Android platforms is pretty partial, but the problem also applies to significant parts of the Android base. In China the problem is near-absolute. Google services are mostly blocked anyway, almost all Android phones ship with few or no Google services installed (i.e. they are based on the open source AOSP version of Android) and hence Google gets close to zero practical benefit from the explosive growth of Android there. There is a similar issue in other emerging markets – a significant portion of those $45 handsets skimp on Google apps just as they skimp on IMEI numbers. For some large and increasing share of the Android market Google’s not only not getting traffic to its own sites. It’s not even getting that user data that makes its ads more valuable. Which leads us to the final question.

Topic.Title: Did Yahoo move its earnings date back 5 days because it wanted numbers from Alibaba?

Message.Msg: I don't recall it being anything less than the 28th, going back to late November/December, as I've been checking it for awhile now. That being said, it really doesn't matter, as Alibaba's revenue numbers have never been included in the quarterly earnings. They shove it in the annual report but it has zero impact on Yahoo's earnings. Earnings themselves I'm guessing are going to be boring as Yahoo is quite predictable...220M+ operating income in Q4, revenue of 1.2-1.3B maybe(flat), less than 5% growth, negative in some sectors and probably bought back $500M-$1B worth of shares judging by the pop in share price. Its possible they spent $1.5B+ which would remove 100M shares, giving the stock an inflated 10% pop. Oh and I expect Yahoo's cash to fall billions either in this quarters earnings or next quarter to cover the Alibaba taxes and stock buyback. On a side note, what is the breakdown to get your "additional $100M" figure? I figure its easier to ask then go digging for Alibaba's revenues times Yahoo's stake. thanks!

Message.Title: AMD NOK & AAPL EARNINGS WEEK Playlist
Message.Msg: Hello Traders, This week alone, two of our long term investments stocks [AMD, NOK] are entering the spotlight. INTC had unsatisfactory news as the stock declined over 5%. This uncertainty brought AMD down as well (over 10%). Most of the long term players should have been stopped out to make sure they at least obtained a 60% profit. If you are looking to play the earnings, we have some suggestions to keep you from having all your eggs in one basket. Normally, one of the best trading strategies for a long term stock being played by a day trader would be to take out 80% of your position before earnings and have the option to reenter if you enjoy the news. NOK will be under the microscope for a while when it comes to the sales during the holiday including their new-phone released during the Q4 (Lumia 920). Again, those who are holding NOK as a long term stock (including the dividends), we are over 90% in gains. Keeping minimal shares in the stock during the news is still a smart move for the future of the company. I would suggest for NOK to hold only 10-15% of the shares for the upcoming earnings report on the 24th. AAPL will have their earnings report Wednesday. Uncertainty can create lots of opportunity for profit if you are willing to play the risk. I won’t lie; playing AAPL this week will be one of the largest risk plays you have come across. But my opinion of Apple is this; if the earnings come out and they are unsatisfactory, the stock will plummet around $450-$475 just on negative momentum. If the earnings come out and they are surprising, the stock will build momentum during the week to $545-$575. A lot of stock analyzers would be broader so they could be right on both ends and act like they had a pervious trade strategy. Here, I am telling the truth and exactly how I am going to play this stock. I am going to the options board here. I am buying two $500 calls for Jan 25th and one $500 put for the earnings. Brought to you by Avida Capital Group.

Topic.Title: Here is why AAPL will post killer numbers for earnings

Message.Msg: The Bloomberg report made a calculation error. I commented the article to correct it. The article states that if apple posts $13.48 EPS, that would be 3% below the previous year. However... If Apple were to post EPS at $13.48, this would NOT constitute a 3% drop from last year. The 2011 December quarter had 13 weeks of sales. The 2012 December quarter will only have 12 weeks of sales. if you compensate for the extra week, $13.48 EPS constitutes an increase of 4.66% year over year.

Topic.Title: I love this quote

Message.Msg: Outstanding! Apple's market share is increasing. The latest stats from Kantar Worldpanel ComTech, released on Tuesday, show that Apple is far from the sickly company that is getting eaten alive by Android. For the 12 weeks ended December 23, 2012, the Apple iPhone represented 51.2% of smartphones purchased in the U.S. That was up sharply from last year's 44.9% share which had given iOS the slimmest of leads over the 44.8% controlled by Android.

Topic.Title: VZ will crash the market and take AAPL down with it

Message.Msg: the comments of an idiot... "watch and learn" alone reveal that; no one with an IQ over 90 would say that. But as for the numbers, even dumber... VZ is not close to important enough to "crash the market." VZ's overall results were good with some unexpectedly high one time charges (Sandy), and while acquisition costs for expensive phones incl iPhone hurt their gross margin, the increased revenues associated with data plans continues to drive higher overall revenues, cash flow and profitability for them. Those aspects are why the iPhone saved Sprint from going out of business -- and why Sprint continues to ambitiously chase iPhone activations. VZ's smartphone activations 4Q were excellent; ALL TIME RECORD HIGH. VZ's iPhone number not yet shared, but they have already said the smartphones sales included "a higher mix of iPhones" than in the prior period. VZ's record numbers are a confirming data point that Demark is correct about seeing "at least 22% higher" (or at least $600) on AAPL this week.

Message.Title: Business Insider – Sun, Jan 20, 2013 11:08 PM EST
Message.Msg: RUMOR: Apple Will Release THREE New iPhones This Year There's a report out of Asia tonight that Apple is working on three new iPhone models, two of which will be out by June. The report comes from quite a chain of sources. The Commercial Times of Taiwan made the original report. It was then picked up by the China Times. Then the China Times report was translated by BrightWire, which says it scours and translates international news. From there, we saw it picked up on Apple blogs. So, yeah. Treat this one lightly for now. Though, a lot of accurate information has come from Asian supply chain sources in the last few years. According to the reports, Apple will release a 4-inch iPhone 5S and a 4.8-inch iPhone before the end of June. The report calls the 4.8-inch phone, the "iPhone Math," which is, um, odd. We can't imagine Apple is going to name its big iPhone the "Math." (But, we also couldn't imagine Apple would name the iPad the iPad and it did! So anything's possible, we suppose.) Later in the year, some time before Christmas another iPhone is coming with a 12 megapixel camera, according to the reports. They also say Apple is going to release an Apple TV this year. The report about a 4.8-inch phone is the most interesting. Apple is the only smartphone company not making a big phone. The bigger smartphones are very popular with consumers.

Message.Title: Apple's 'black ice' predicted to 'thaw' by summer, pushing stock back toward $700
Message.Msg: With 2013 off to a tough start for Apple stock, one analyst attempted to ease investor concerns on Friday, noting that comparisons to a strong 2012 will begin to ease as the year goes on. A year ago, the iPhone 4S and iPhone 4 shared common components, helping to boost Apple's gross margins, Maynard Um of Wells Fargo Securities said in a note to investors on Friday. Along with a record setting launch of the iPhone 4S in the 2011 December quarter, he believes it could make for a tough comparison for Apple for the start of the year. But Um sees Apple's difficult 2012 comparisons easing as the year goes on. He expects that Apple's next iPhone, the so-called "iPhone 5S," will share design similarities to the current iPhone 5, helping to improve margins. Because of that, Apple's current "black ice," as Um put it, is predicted to "thaw through summer." He sees easier comparisons to 2012 along with improving gross margins, which could improve sentiment among investors. "While this requires some patience as the cycle transitions and then matures to drive gross margin, we believe valuation will rise with sentiment," Um said. "While there seems to be some concern around competition and diminishing demand, had some operators not been as restrictive on upgrades relative to past new product launches, Apple would have experienced an even stronger launch, making what we expect to be a record setting December even more impressive." Wells Fargo Securities has a projected valuation range for AAPL stock from $680 to $730. That's a wider range than their previous forecast of $710 to $730. For the December quarter, Um expects Apple sold 48 million iPhone units, with about three quarters of those being the new iPhone 5. And iPad sales are projected to be 20.2 million, with about half of them being the iPad mini, dropping the average selling price to $450. His revenue estimate of $53 billion is below consensus of $54.7 billion, while his earnings per share forecast of $13.67 is above the Street's $13.41.

Message.Title: Apple shipped 52 million iPhones in Q4 to buoy quarterly earnings
Message.Msg: Contrary to rumors of significant shortfalls, Apple will post positive results for the fourth quarter of 2012 as strong iOS device shipments more than made up for iPad mini and iMac supply chain issues, one market analyst says. In a note to investors on Tuesday, the well-connected Ming-Chi Kuo of KGI Securities expects Apple to post good fourth quarter earnings despite worries sparked by recent rumblings of iPhone shipment cuts. In fact, the analyst believes that Apple's handset will be one of the few product lines to beat consensus. Kuo estimates Apple's "main products," like the iPhone and iPad, saw quarter-to-quarter shipments rise over the last three months of 2012, but warns that shipments of specific devices within those lines may fall short of expectations. iPhone shipments have been center stage over the past week after Apple reportedly made significant cuts to parts suppliers in December. Despite the rumors, Kuo cites supply chain checks and says Apple shipped 52 million units during quarter four to be up 93 percent quarter-on-quarter and up 41 percent year-to-year. A breakdown by model shows shipments of the newest iPhone #$%$ more than 35 million units for the fourth quarter, which is a 3.5 percent negative adjustment to Kuo's previous forecast of 36.5 million. Fourth quarter shipments of the iPhone 4S and iPhone 4 followed far behind at 9.5 million and 7.3 million, respectively. Overall, Apple is expected to have moved over 140 million smartphones in 2012, led by strong iPhone 4S shipments of some 74 million units during the first half of the year. As for the iPad, Kuo's forecast comes in at 23 million units shipped for the three-month period ending in December, or a 49 percent increase from the same time last year. The fourth-generation iPad will come in with 9.3 million shipped units while the newly introduced iPad mini will see 8.2 million shipments. Kuo notes the estimates are down slightly from previous forecasts due to poor demand for the full-size iPad and supply chain issues with the smaller version of Apple's popular tablet. Most significant, says Kuo, was a bottleneck at AU Optronic, one of the iPad mini's main LCD panel suppliers. Looking ahead, Apple's supply chain woes are expected to stabilize in the first quarter of 2013. Year-to-year iOS shipment growth is pegged at 6.5 percent for the iPhone and 64 percent for the iPad, accounting for over 37 million and 19.4 million units, respectively

Topic.Title: Will these catalysts raise stock value above $1000 a share this year?

Message.Msg: For Apple, this year is about removing the product/pricing umbrellas that exist in smartphones. They must execute successful launches of both a less expensive iPhone to address the pricing umbrella Samsung currently enjoys at the low end. They also must successfully launch a larger iPhone to address the product umbrella Samsung currently enjoys in the larger smartphone segment. Other items I believe are very important to turn off the negative sentiment are as follows: BIG Q1 numbers tomorrow China Mobile Increase dividend Compelling changes with iOS 7 Successful/very cool iTV EPS FY13 $55 I believe if most of these happen this year the pps by EOY will be over $750. Now, we wait patiently. Good luck longs!!

Message.Title: Verizon (VZ) CFO Says 9.8M Smartphones Sold in Q4; 6.2M Were iPhones (AAPL)
Message.Msg: Verizon Communications (NYSE: VZ) CFO Fran Shammo said 9.8 million smartphones were sold in the fourth-quarter 2012. Notably, this compares with 10 million reported by AT (NYSE: T) earlier in January. Of the total, 6.2 million were Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL) iPhones and 3.6 million were Google (Nasdaq: GOOG) Android-based devices.

Message.Title: VZ Results: GREAT NEWS FOR AAPL LONGS
Message.Msg: One of the unhedged short gumps here this morning suggests VZ teh suk and will hurt AAPL. T o repeat myself he is an idiot. Then I said this: "VZ is not close to important enough to "crash the market." VZ's overall results were good with some unexpectedly high one time charges (Sandy), and while acquisition costs for expensive phones incl iPhone hurt their gross margin, the increased revenues associated with data plans continues to drive higher overall revenues, cash flow and profitability for them. Those aspects are why the iPhone saved Sprint from going out of business -- and why Sprint continues to ambitiously chase iPhone activations. VZ's smartphone activations 4Q were excellent; ALL TIME RECORD HIGH. VZ's iPhone number not yet shared, but they have already said the smartphones sales included "a higher mix of iPhones" than in the prior period. VZ's record numbers are a confirming data point that Demark is correct about seeing "at least 22% higher" (or at least $600) on AAPL this week." Listening to the VZ call now, the first few minutes are all about the strong smartphone sales subsidies (largely iphones) and the fact that their future service revenues will be greatly enhanced by these products. The unhedged AAPL shorts will be skewered this week; it's time for them to begin panic buying ahead of the blowout AAPL results tomorrow. DeMark and Gore have some insight that gumptards do not... so does Dan, Horace, Gene. HERE COMES THE Q&A...

Message.Title: This will rise...
Message.Msg: ...Ahead of earnings but it is anyone's guess as to where it will head. If it beats estimates which have been lowered anyway by analysts, then of course it will rise but how much? It's time to be pragmatic. Earnings are beginning to lower as are profits. Chinese won't pay premium on Apple products. They don't operate that way so consummating a telecommunications deal in China isn't as big a deal as many believe especially knowing there is major telecom competition within. Yes competition abounds but there is a larger problem:: Vertical Integration: Without innovation of new products and seizing the market for these products Apple will lose market share. Customers who have not owned an Apple product to date won't be flocking to the door. The existing Apple customer base is solidified but saturated. Yes they will update their phone but less frequently. People get bored. it is human nature especially in today's fast moving world of IT. Without innovation the company will compromise the brand if they attempt to compete horizontally with less expensive products. I can't see them doing this and therefore they will need to captivate their existing and new clients with daring innovation. It could and probably will happen but not immediately IMO. That being said I think holding a position here is like walking a high wire especially with the state of the US & global economies.. The technicals spell a further drop with support being much lower. Good luck in your investment. I'm waiting until earning come out knowing I might miss a big jump. So be it...I've profited nicely to date from this great company.

Message.Title: Apple price target cut from $7oo to $650 at UBS on iPhone selling price worries .
Message.Msg: UBS analysts have cut their estimate of the average selling price for Apple AAPL+0.88% iPhones and reduced their earnings estimate and price target for the stock. Steven Milunovich, Peter Christiansen, and John Roy cite survey data showing that demand for storage has fallen from around 30GB with the older iPhone 4S model to 20GB with the iPhone 5. In addition, fewer customers are opting for the 64GB models of the newer phone, and demand for older models has risen from 33% in the 4S product cycle to 50% in the iPhone 5 cycle so far. The analysts say iPhone’s gross margin could suffer 8 to 10 points because of the downward product shift and higher costs of launching the new phone. “We maintain our Buy rating in the belief that risk-reward is favourable given improving growth, a China Mobile deal by C4Q, and skepticism about innovation,” they wrote in a note Tuesday. The analysts cut their fiscal 2013 earnings per share estimate to $44.68 from $47. They cut their price target to $650 from $700. Apple is slated to report its latest quarterly results on Wednesday. – Tom Bemis

Message.Title: Read Verizon news a very good indicator for a great AAPL quarter!!! Heading much higher today!!!
Message.Msg: Brian White, the very bullish Apple analyst at Topeka Capital Markets, calls Tuesday’s Verizon VZ +0.61% report good news for the iPhone maker. Verizon reported its 4Q12 results and discussed iPhone activations. Verizon announced 6.2 million iPhone activations in 4Q12 and double the 3.1 million activated in 3Q12. Approximately 50% of the iPhones were described as 4G LTE, which equates to the iPhone 5. As such, it appears as if the iPhone 4S and iPhone 4 were particularly strong in the quarter. Over the past six quarters, Verizon has accounted for approximately 11% of Apple’s total iPhone shipments. Using this 11% number, we can easily back into a greater than 56 million iPhone shipment number in the quarter. Even with 12% penetration, we can get over 51 million. White has a price target of $1,111 on Apple

Message.Title: Nansen Investments calculates 58.73 million Apple Iphones for last Q!
Message.Msg: Verizon is reporting 6.2 MM iPhones sold in the Holiday Quarter. Previously I had been a little bold and projected 5.68 MM iPhones sold by Verizon in the holiday quarter. 6.2 MM is quite a bit better than I had hoped for. We have pretty tight statistics for Verizon’s share of worldwide sales of the iPhone for the last 4 quarters. I list the last 4 quarters below with Verizon’s share of worldwide iPhone sales. Taking the last 4 quarters average gives us an average projection of 58.73 MM iPhones sold worldwide for Apple’s Q1. I am feeling a lot better this morning about my projection of 54 MM iPhones and a 16.00 EPS. ■Quarter Verizon’s % share of World Sales Est. iPhones ■Q1 2012 11.61% 53.40 MM ■Q2 2012 9.13% 67.91 MM ■Q3 2012 10.37% 59.79 MM ■Q4 2012 11.52% 53.82 MM ■AVG 58.73 MM I am looking at this 58.73 MM projection for Q1 and one bullish thought keeps asserting itself and that is the fact that Apple rolled out its international sales much quicker for Q1 2013 than it did for Q1 2012. That makes me feel more confident that this projection is in the ball park. Apple is sitting on the lowest expectations in its history. The surrounding negative sentiment is the worst that I have seen in its history. The bar is low. If Apple comes in with 58.73 MM iPhones, it will be North of 16.00 EPS. This will be the biggest shock in Apple’s history. The drama has definitely been ratcheted up by this report. ---Silverhorseshoe

Message.Title: Verizon Announced 6.2M Iphone Activations: Double 3Q12
Message.Msg: “Verizon reported its 4Q12 results and discussed iPhone activations. Verizon announced 6.2 million iPhone activations in 4Q12 and double the 3.1 million activated in 3Q12. Approximately 50% of the iPhones were described as 4G LTE, which equates to the iPhone 5. As such, it appears as if the iPhone 4S and iPhone 4 were particularly strong in the quarter. Over the past six quarters, Verizon has accounted for approximately 11% of Apple’s total iPhone shipments. Using this 11% number, we can easily back into a greater than 56 million iPhone shipment number in the quarter. Even with 12% penetration, we can get over 51 million.”

Topic.Title: RIP TO $600 THIS WEEK

Message.Msg: $600 tomorrow?!?! What?!?! Why?!?! No one is a stronger long in aapl than me. But, these kinds of opinions on the bullish side are equally ridiculous to those bearish opinions calling for aapl at $350. I am bullish...very bullish. I believe the earnings will be strong, if not a huge blow out. But, there are many market forces at play in aapl right now. To relieve the stock of these forces and the overwhelming negative sentiment, I believe it will take most of 2013. Apple must execute on addressing smartphone competitive concerns with both product and pricing changes. This is key for 2013, and is necessary for the sentiment to go positive. I say the pps will exceed $750 EOY if they successfully address the iPhone market challenges by introducing a lower priced iPhone and a larger iPhone...both profitably.
$448 will be new 52 week lows... AAPL will be considered Wall Street's biggest Dog

Message.Msg: Solazyme, Inc. operates as a renewable oil production company. The Company fuels include microbial-derived jet fuels, bio-diesels, and renewable diesels. The Company also offers marine and microaquatic compounds for health and wellness products. Its products are used for biofuel production, replacements for fossil petroleum, and plant oils in various products ranging from green household cleaning supplies to cosmetics and foods. The Company serves renewable energy and industrial chemicals markets, as well as specialty ingredients markets in cosmetic, nutritional, and pharmaceutical products.

Message.Title: AAPL TAKING ASHARE FROM ANDROID AGAIN (i5)
Message.Msg: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) may have gotten a string of bad news about its products recently, but according to a new survey, its iOS platform continues to be the market leader in the U.S. and is stealing users away from rivals Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) and Research In Motion (NASDAQ:RIMM). According to Kantar Worldpanel ComTech data, Apple’s iOS accounted for 51.2 percent of all U.S. smartphone sales for the 12-week period ending December 23, 2012. This represented a growth of more than 7 percent from the 44.9 percent over the same period in 2011. Meanwhile, Android’s share fell from 44.8 percent in 2011 to 44.2 percent, while RIM suffered an even bigger decline — falling from 6.1 percent of smartphone sales to 1.1 percent. “Apple’s continual improvement is thanks to both the iPhone 5 and older models attracting various customer groups, from repeat Apple buyers, first time smartphone buyers and those coming from other smartphone brands,” Kantar’s Mary-Ann Parlato said in a statement. According to Parlato, 36 percent of iOS sales were derived from other smartphone users over the last year, including 19 percent from Android users. That was up from 9 percent Android converts in 2011.

Message.Title: Verizon (VZ) states on its Q4 call it activated 6.2M iPhones in Q4. Check AT&T next.
Message.Msg: Tuesday, January 22, 9:21 AM ET Verizon (VZ) states on its Q4 call it activated 6.2M iPhones in Q4, good for 63% of total smartphone activations (up from 46% in Q3, and 56% in the year-ago period). Big Red had previously disclosed it activated 9.8M smartphones in the quarter. CFO Fran Shammo says about half of the iPhone sales involved the iPhone 5 - that remark comes as UBS points to survey data indicating a mix shift towards older and lower-capacity iPhone models. Apple (AAPL) +0.8%. (AT&T smartphone sales)

Topic.Title: FACTS: aapl definitely is DECELERATING its growth

Message.Msg: OK, so it has decelerated from amazing 50 - 60% growth a year ago, to more sustainable 15 - 20% this coming year. Big deal. Those are still growh % very few S&P 500 companies have, and Intel just reported 3% sales drop due to Microsoft Windows systems going down in the market. Fact is IBM and MSFT and INTEL and DELL have combined growth rates of about 5% or 0%, and yet have PE Ratios above Apple's. Apple is gaining ground vs. all these companies, taking market share from them, actually it is Apple that shoudl have a higher PE. Instead it is MSFT with the 15 PE, oddly.

Message.Title: VZ signals Jaw Dropping iPhone sales
Message.Msg: We have ~30 hours until Apple tells us how many iPhones it sold during the holiday quarter. Until then, we're left to guess. Right now, the Street's consensus is around 48 million units. But, Topeka Capital analyst Brian White says that if you use Verizon's just announced iPhone sales as a guide, Apple could demolish expectations. Verizon sold 6.2 million iPhones last quarter. Historically, Verizon has been about 11% of iPhone sales. If that holds, then Apple will have sold 56 million iPhones, says White. Even if it's 12% of iPhone sales, Apple could have sold 51 million. It's big if. Things change. The rest of the world may have grown tired of the iPhone last quarter. But, it's hard to look at this Verizon iPhone number as anything but good news for Apple.

Message.Title: APPLE is just getting started
Message.Msg: According to Kantar Worldpanel ComTech data, Apple’s iOS accounted for 51.2 percent of all U.S. smartphone sales for the 12-week period ending December 23, 2012. This represented a growth of more than 7 percent from the 44.9 percent over the same period in 2011. Meanwhile, Android’s share fell from 44.8 percent in 2011 to 44.2 percent, while RIM suffered an even bigger decline — falling from 6.1 percent of smartphone sales to 1.1 percent.

Message.Title: BMO Capital's Keith Bachman warns of earnings estimates. VZ#s not good
Message.Msg: BMO Capital's Keith Bachman offered some comments on Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) following Verizon's (NYSE: VZ) iPhone numbers. Verizon sold 9.8 million smartphones in the December quarter, including 6.2 million iPhone units, which were modestly above the firm's 5.6 million iPhone estimate. While better, the analyst notes mix is a concern. Despite launching late in the September quarter, the iPhone 5 contributed only 3.1 million units in the December quarter, or approximately 50%, he notes. "We believe the lower mix of iPhone 5 units will put downside pressure on ASPs. In past product launches, the new generation of iPhone models would account for the vast majority of sales, which helped ASPs." Despite the comments, the analyst is still positive on the stock. He reiterated an Outperform rating and price target of $640, saying he believes that Apple could meaningfully increase both dividends and buybacks, which would help support the stock. For an analyst ratings summary and ratings history on Apple click here. For more ratings news on Apple click here.

Message.Title: iPhone Sales
Message.Msg: Most people, namely analysts, seem to be primarily modeling 51-55 million iPhones. However, they seem to be excluding "pent up demand." In other words, their models are missing what I think are about 6-8 million *additional* sales, due to the carryover from purchases that were NOT made last quarter. Take the midpoint of the 51-55 estimates, add the midpoint of the 6-8 in pent up demand from last quarter, and you arrive at about 60 million iPhones. I truly believe the number will between 58-62 million iPhones, so I'll say 60 million.

Message.Msg: This guy has been brilliant on August until aapl's last two quarters, but his bullishness is even more notable in that context. Tuesday, January 15, 2013 Fiscal 1Q 2013 Final Estimates at 11:20 PM As of Tuesday's closing price of $485.92, AAPL is trading at 8.3x my forward EPS estimate (5.9x ex-cash). This extremely low forward valuation is similar to that of mid 2011, when it traded in the mid $300s ahead of $44 EPS for FY2012 and mid $80s in cash per share at the time. The stock ended up doubling a year later. Interestingly, my (lowered) target now implies a doubling of the current price over the next 12-18 months. HIS NUMBERS MAY GO UP TONIGHT BASED ON VZ DATA. Message.Title: Verizon Sales - Same quarter last year (with an extra week of sales)
Message.Msg: Chew on this shorts.... The same time last year, when Apple destroyed earnings at $13.30 (nearly $4 above company consensus), Verizon sold 7.7 million phones for the same quarter, with 4.3 million being Iphones. The sales represented 50% of Verizon sales. This year, in the wake of all the gloom and doom, Verizon sold 9.8 million phones, with 6.2 million accounting for Iphone. That's 58% of all phones sold at Verizon. So looking at Apple's best ever quarter last year, against this year's Verizon numbers, why the heck are so many people down on this stock???? Few more points. Last year's Verizon numbers had an extra week of sales, and were still much lower than this year. Last year Apple wasn’t selling Iphone AT ALL in China yet. No sales went into that quarter. This year they are selling like hot cakes at China Unicom and Telecom this past quarter (2 million in first day of sales). Lastly, there was no Ipad mini last year, no revamp of macbook, mac pro, etc.

Message.Msg: Been in AAPL for years, and lately been more out. In at moment. Don't believe Cook creates the needed respect from employees, let alone the ball thrashing he takes from MM's. He will need to CRUSH earnings and give accurate forward guidance that is in excess of 25%, along with announcing China Mobile deal. Cook and AAPL have allowed AAPL stock to be manipulated. His and AAPL's disdain for share holders has fueled the downturn. Can't say that after earnings bump will retain any shares unless there is a substantive change in AAPL culture. Cook thus far has failed. Product rollouts were stuff "on the shelf". Much like academia, "publish or perish", AAPL needs to shockingly innovate in order to stave the negativity. AAPL's contribution during the recent campaign, IMO, only fomented additional reprisals. The stock market has never before been such a casino. Either control your fate, or bend over. We'll see which Cook chooses.

Topic.Title: Verizon Sales - Same quarter last year (with an extra week of sales)

Message.Msg: I appreciate your sentiment, but your numbers seem to be wrong. Last year Apple reported EPS at $13.87, not $13.30 Last year the iPhone comprised 55.8% of Verizon phone sales, not 50% This year the iPhone comprised 63.3% of Verizon phone sales, not 58% And, as you say, this iPhone growth at Verizon took place in a quarter with only 12 weeks, rather than 13. Last year Verizon comprised 11.61% of World-wide iPhone sales Due to expansion of international availability we can assume that Verizon's importance has shrunk slightly. Let's be very conservative. Lets say Verizon now only makes up 11% of world-wide sales. That would mean that Apple sold 58 million iPhones. Yes, 58 million. Analysts are expecting 48-52 million. If Verizon's share of world-wide sales is 10%, then Apple sold 63.7 million phones If Verizon's share of world-wide sales is 9%, then Apple sold 70.8 million phones Shorts, I am not trying to trash talk you. but seriously. just cover now. there is no reason why we all cant be winners. This earnings call is going to be a blow out.

Message.Title: Verizon is a Microcosm of smartphone market
Message.Msg: Last year Verizon comprised 11.61% of world-wide iPhone sales But since Apple has greatly expanded international availability we must assume that Verizon's share has shrunk slightly. Let's be very conservative. Lets say Verizon now only makes up 11% of world-wide sales. That would mean that Apple sold 58 million iPhones. Yes, 58 million. Analysts are expecting 48-52 million. If Verizon's share of world-wide sales is 10%, then Apple sold 63.7 million phones If Verizon's share of world-wide sales is 9%, then Apple sold 70.8 million phones Shorts, I am not trying to trash talk you. but seriously. just cover now. there is no reason why we all cant be winners. Message.Title: Tomorrow prediction
Marissa Mayer's Plan To Save Yahoo Suddenly Looks Much Different Than Anyone Predicted
Message.Msg: First there was Yahoo's recently completed deal with CBS to bring new content into its gossip site, OMG. Next, there were the remarks Mayer's recently-hired number two and fellow ex-Googler, COO Henrique De Castro, gave over at a conference in Germany. He said that “the desktop portal needs to transform itself" and that the best ones going forward would "aggregate premium quality content at scale, and distribute it in a personalized way.” And now there's a report from All Things D's Kara Swisher about a secret project Mayer has Yahoo working on called "Project Zed." Multiple sources tell Swisher the plan is to make Yahoo a "destination where people go to find content regardless of where it originates from; the better Yahoo gets at making it more relevant, the more it becomes part of people’s everyday routine and the more repeat visitors there are.” Another says it will be a “trusted destination to get them to where they want to go and keep going back.” When Mayer was hired, people thought that meant Yahoo was going to be a "products" company. It's not. It's not a "media" company either. With Mayer running the show, and some of Levinsohn's ideas moving forward, it's becoming what it always should have been – a media + products company.

Message.Title: The iPhone Lifted The Canadian Economy in Q4 LOL
Message.Msg: The iPhone 5 launched here last September, but it took two months — until November — for the latest sought-after handset to influence the Canadian economy. With the release Tuesday of November retail sales – which beat expectations with a 0.2% month-over-month gain — economists indicate the country’s gross domestic product in the month might have advanced 0.2% to 0.3%. Some economists say November’s strong performance can be attributed to the latest Apple gadget. “That appears to be driver,” said Benjamin Reitzes, senior economist at BMO Capital Markets.

Message.Title: If projections based on VZ point to 55M, we could see 60M+
Message.Msg: Those projections aren't accounting for filling of the channel. This is good for an additional 6-11M iPhones. Apple entered the quarter with about 10M in the channel and usually aims for 4-6 weeks of inventory. So we could be looking at anywhere from 61M to 66M iPhones for the quarter. Couple that with 25M iPads, 39% GM, and we may be pushing $16-17 in EPS for the quarter. Food for thought.

Topic.Title: HEADLINE HEADLINE BLOOMBERG APPLE BRACES FOR PROFIT DROP .WARNING WARNING AAPLE COULD WARN IN COMING QUARERS AND 2013COULD CRASH OVER $100

Message.Msg: The iPhone may be in store for a tough quarter, according to one analyst. Apple will give up some of its smartphone market share this quarter, “raising concern about the on-going dominance of the iPhone,” Citi analyst Glen Yeung said in an investors note out today. He cited strong demand for Samsung devices as the reason. . . ”Our checks mid-December revealed initial signs of order cuts from Apple, now evident across a larger array of suppliers,” the analyst said. “We acknowledge the true nature of these cuts is as yet inconclusive, but we suspect they reflect growing demand for competitive offerings (e.g. Samsung), particularly outside the U.S.” Assuming the cuts signal the likely number of shipments, Yeung sees iPhone units sales of 35 million this quarter. That’s below Wall Street’s consensus of around 42 million.

Message.Title: WSJ: Canada Economy Gets a Charge in November from iPhone 5
Message.Msg: WSJ APPARENTLY FINDING SOME OBJECTIVITY? NEGATIVE SENTIMENT TURNONG ON A DIME NOW? WAIT UNTIL THEY SEE SMASHED SANDBAGGED ESTIMATES/RESTORED CONFIDENCE. January 22, 2013, 1:30 PM The iPhone 5 launched in Canada last September. Apple Inc. AAPL +0.46%’s iPhone 5 continues to generate buzz…this time in the Canadian economy. Demand for cellphones and electronic equipment was a major factor in three key pieces of Canadian economic data in November — international trade, wholesale trade, and retail sales. The iPhone 5 launched here last September, but it took two months — until November — for the latest sought-after handset to influence the Canadian economy. With the release Tuesday of November retail sales – which beat expectations with a 0.2% month-over-month gain — economists indicate the country’s gross domestic product in the month might have advanced 0.2% to 0.3%. Some economists say November’s strong performance can be attributed to the latest Apple gadget. “That appears to be driver,” said Benjamin Reitzes, senior economist at BMO Capital Markets. Representatives for BCE Inc. BCE.T +0.51% and Rogers Communications Inc. RCI.B.T -0.04%, the two biggest wireless providers in Canada, weren’t immediately available for comment. Industry analysts noted there were supply constraints for the iPhone 5 as display screens, made by Sharp Corp. 6753.TO -3.02% & LG Display Co. 034220.SE +2.81%, fell short of initial demand. In Canada, this pushed some iPhone 5 unit shipments out from October to November. And that showed up in some of the November economic data. Here’s how it breaks down: DETAILS ON THE WSJ PAGE

Message.Title: *** iPhones are selling like hotcakes ***
Message.Msg: This morning, Verizon (VZ) topped some estimates and announced it had sold 6.2 million iPhones during its fourth quarter—an all-time high—leading RBC Capital Markets analysts Amit Daryanani and Mark Sue to suss out the numbers. Of those 6.2 million Verizon iPhones purchased domestically, 50%, or 3.1 million, were iPhone 5s. That compares favorably with the 3.1 million Verizon iPhones sold in total the quarter prior. Still AT&T came out on top. The country's largest carrier is projected to have moved 8.1 million iPhones. (Sprint trailed behind with just over 1.7 million sold.) The only major carrier not to get some love from Apple, T-Mobile, should see that situation change soon enough. Earlier this year, CEO John Legere told Reuters he expects the company to start offering the iPhone within the next four months.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Brian White, the very bullish Apple analyst at Topeka Capital Markets, calls Tuesday’s Verizon report good news for the iPhone maker. “Verizon reported its 4Q12 results and discussed iPhone activations. Verizon announced 6.2 million iPhone activations in 4Q12 and double the 3.1 million activated in 3Q12. Approximately 50% of the iPhones were described as 4G LTE, which equates to the iPhone 5. As such, it appears as if the iPhone 4S and iPhone 4 were particularly strong in the quarter. Over the past six quarters, Verizon has accounted for approximately 11% of Apple’s total iPhone shipments. Using this 11% number, we can easily back into a greater than 56 million iPhone shipment number in the quarter. Even with 12% penetration, we can get over 51 million.” White has a price target of $1,111 on Apple .

Topic.Title: WHY MARGINS WILL SURPRISE TO THE UPSIDE (38% GUIDED, 39% CONSENSUS)

Message.Msg: REASON NUMBER 11 -- Beyond selling more iphones than contemplated at VZ and likely the other carriers around the world as well, the I5 SUPPLY IMBALANCE MEANS MORE CONSUMERS TOOK THE I4 AND I4S than previously contemplated at VZ and likely T and Sprint (the latter is biased to the other phones because they won't have LTE capacity until later this year). This means lower subsidies for the carriers in the quarter, but MAXIMUM margins for AAPL because they are coming off of the very seasoned, high yield production lines vs the early i5 runs where the learning curve yield and defective backs/glass issues were not yet ironed out and hence would have had lower yields. The i5 supply demand curve is in balance now, and margins are already way up the curve as a result, so this is all great news for aapl. Additionally, it is serving to blow out inventory of the oldr phones, likely just before AAPL sharply curtails or eliminates the iphone 4 lines... gee, d'ya think maybe that was some of the parts order curtailment bs? AAPL numbers will be great tomorrow as I've been saying... but now we have confirming data from ATT, VZ, Canada, Al Gore's early option exercise, and more... Tomorrow will be grand for longs, especially as margin departments go to work on unhedged shorts and as hedged shorts on pro positions continue to come off in tippy toe fashion as seen this afternoon and in taking advantage of moronic algo shorting today. LOL

Message.Title: GUIDANCE, CONSENSUS AND SMASHING BEATS
Message.Msg: TOMORROW SHOULD CLEAR THE DECKS OF ALL THE NAYSAYERS ON THE BUSINESS PLAN, forward revenues, guidance and spreads to guidance and consensus revenues. Why? We expect that even if Tim and his cfo and IR staff people don't understand you can't have a 7 year smash guidance pattern followed by just barely beating the guidance and missing the consensus during the june and Sep Q, well, someone like Bog Iger and say the top 10 or so sellside analysts and large shareholders have no doubt chimed in on my point here. This thread covers the key issue that has thrashed AAPL stock price since early october and the early stumbles meeting i5 and Mini ipad demand , a spiral which was not really about anything other than those stumbles and the balance of this thread (we debunked the bs tax selling myth on various threads). in short, the mistakes made on the guidance/UPOD pattern screwed the stock, so badly one would have to try to ruin confidence and the entire symmetry more than they did. Let's get onto it... AAPL smashed guidance every quarter over the last 6 years and also beat estimates every one of those quarters -- except for 3 quarters. Those three included the last 2! What went wrong? AAPL had consistently sandbagged the snot out of their estimates -- beating by a range of 31-50%+ in every one of those quarters except for the three I'm discussing. In the last two quarters, they beat their guidance on revs and EPS, but by less than 10%, destroying the historical pattern that they had lulled pro shareowners and analysts alike to sleep with! The cfo and IR players should have known that would shatter street confidence in them -- and all the longs can hope I'm right that they will smash guidance again restoring everyones' confidence in the story, growth and mgmt... You may have noticed that the current consensus is right on top of what ought to be crazy sandbagged revenue and margin and eps guidance -- analysts cant afford to be too high again. Tim has it now!

Message.Msg: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Google Inc. /quotes/zigman/93888/quotes/nls/goog GOOG +3.71% on Tuesday reported a fourth-quarter profit of $2.89 billion, or $8.62 a share, compared with a profit of $2.71 billion, or $8.22 a share, for the year-earlier period. On a non-GAAP basis, Google reported a profit of $10.65 a share for the recent quarter. Revenue minus traffic acquisition costs was $11.34 billion, up from $8.13 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters on average expected the Internet giant to report a profit of $10.47 a share, on revenue of $12.34 billion. Shares of Google were up more than 4% in after-hours trading

Topic.Title: Too many think too small here

Message.Msg: I'd rather think small than incorrectly. Comparing Google to Apple based on market valuations is like comparing the interstate 5 freeway to Disney Land. Do the tolls collected on a major interstate freeway reflect the level of underlying value and power it wields of economic activity? Apple is simply a discretionary consumer product, if it's not making money, it has no value. Google on the other hand has a value far beyond its P&L statements, so it cannot be judged by apples metrics.

Message.Title: re: economic return
Message.Msg: For those of you that don't/can't comprehend. Forward PE is a function of the markets rejected "economic return." If the market values Apple at a lower forward PE than Google, this DOES NOT represent an arbitrage opportunity within the paradigm of efficient markets, it simple means that the markets DOES NOT ascribe the same sustainability characteristic to one business model over the other. It is CLEAR, as far as the market is concerned that Apple IS FAR LESS SUSTAINABLE than Google. Compare Apple to a good house flip. I could buy Apple right now for ~500 bil, raid the coffers for ~130, break even in 2-3 years, then make a nice ~100 bil on top before GOOGLE DE-INDEXES IT. L, O, L.

Topic.Title: re: economic return

Message.Msg: That is also true for googls present pe.. So analysis of the forward pe for your argument does not say anything that is not already a fact! But considering the ratios of present to forward tells u which company is expected to grow better in earnings. I would recommend one to focus more on Peg.. I think it us a much better indication if a stocks value. Present pe can be subject to a lot of hype and momentum. Take amazon at pe of 3100 for example! Yet puny margins and no profit. What kind if growth will justify this value?.. Apple though is considered very undervalued due to its super low peg. And pe !.

Message.Title: 'My Bet Is Up in Apple': Jon Najarian
Message.Msg: "You'd expect that since Apple is implying a 7 percent move, that its implied volatility would be double that, and you would be right," he said. "Apple's implied vol at 93 is implying a move of $36 or more for those earnings." Najarian added that investors were probably fading Apple, IBM and Google because they had thought how to price them last week when Apple's stock price hung around the $500 level. "I don't think we're going to pin this week. I think it's going to make a move up or down," he said. "My bet is up in Apple right now."

Topic.Title: New trading range will be $630 to $665. Get used to it

Message.Msg: I 100% with you on this one. I think that it can be there in a month or two. $700 is a fairly conservative price given current business. AAPL's been over $700 recently and should be able to get back there quickly. EPS in 2013 are easily over $50 per share and more likely pushing $60. By the end of 2013 the net cash and investments, assuming no major investments, would be near $200 per share. Not even counting cash a P/E of 14 on the low end $50 of earnings gets us $700. Add back cash, higher actual earnings potential, and new products in the pipeline, then $700 per share is cheap. So, spiking above $750 in the modest future should be doable. Eventually APPL goes to 4 digits if there isn't a split.

Topic.Title: I admit I bashed while I was long so I could add in the 480's. It was success

Message.Msg: Funny, I can understand that. I have been an AAPL investor for many years, since the Ipod (Napster let me see the future) and when my youngest son went to college and chose an Apple. I always invest on what young people like. But over the years I learned to understand AAPL's irrationality in the stock market. There were times when it dropped 50% and it made no sense. Its cash value was so high, it was impervious to the recession. Yet its stock suffered. But then, mega moves. We are about to see a mega move. AAPL will report stellar profits. The guidance will be sandbagging and a lot of shorters will use that as propaganda. But anyone who has been in AAPL for the last ten years, they know that AAPL is riding the wave of change. Microsoft is dead. Long live the new king! Basher,I sold my AAPL as it dropped from 700 and avoided big losses. After a while you can tell when a stock is being bashed for no reason and know to get out and fight another day . But ultimately, you could have bought and held AAPL ten years ago and just gone to sleep. AAPL is the only viable operating system for phones , tablets and laptops. And for the life of me, who owns a laptop and why? AAPL will double in the next two years, if not sooner. By the way, I am an electrical engineer '78 with an MBA '81. I have invested in high tech since the beginning of Silicon Valley.

Message.Title: When I say YHOO sold AG stake for so cheap (yet has not even used the cash except for free I-phones and gourmet food) I mean....
Message.Msg: ...YHOO sold AG just last May as if AG was worth only $34 bil. in total when it is now trading at an equiv. of a bit over $50 bil, (with an IPO expected to be perhaps much higher). So YHOO left a LOT on the table to Ma's -a sleaze who has screwed YHOO before-benefit. Notice that Softbank did NOT sell any stake back to Ma!! Now YHOO's move would be ok (just to break the impass w/ Ma) IF they had used that money to greatly reduce YHOO share count, (dutch auction?) and/or do a big dividend. They did not even need the cash but all YHOO has done is collect very small interest on all that money. So Kara S. can write articles that send YHOO down by billions in a day and Mayer does not have the sense to support the price with the cash and announced buyback but instead lets YHOO holders get screwed, and YHOO shorts win, and Kara make her look the fool (angain at the expense of YHOO holders). But MM does not take Kara's phone calls so she is really showing her, as YHOO owners lose once again. Thanks a lot MM!!!

Message.Msg: From All Things D: If Apple has been cutting iPhone component orders because of waning demand — as some reports claim — you wouldn’t know it from the latest Kantar Worldpanel ComTech data. For the final quarter of 2012, the iPhone captured 51.2 percent of all U.S. smartphone sales, beating Google’s Android, whose share declined to 44.8 percent, Kantar says. Now that’s just one data point, but there are a few others that belie those reports of slipping demand. Verizon said this morning that about two-thirds of the smartphones it activated in the fourth quarter were iPhones. And then there was AT&T’s announcement earlier this month that its fourth quarter saw “the best-ever quarterly sales of Android and Apple smartphones.” So, in the United States — the world’s second-largest smartphone market by volume — the iPhone was the top-selling smartphone in the fourth quarter. And it was a big seller at the country’s top two wireless carriers. Sound to you like a device for which demand is waning? No one but the folks in Cupertino know for sure. But we’ll all find out tomorrow when Apple reports earnings.

Topic.Title: New Data Belie Reports of Fading iPhone Demand

Message.Msg: From the New York Time..... " Reports last week suggested that people might finally be tired of Apple’s iPhone, citing sources that said sales were weaker than expected. But the latest numbers do not support that conclusion. On Tuesday, Verizon Communications said in its quarterly earnings report that the iPhone was its top-selling smartphone. It sold 9.8 million smartphones over the past quarter, 6.2 million of which were iPhones. Nearly half of the iPhone sales were of iPhone 5s, Verizon said. AT&T, the second-biggest American carrier after Verizon, will report its earnings Thursday, but it has already said that its iPhone sales were strong. In a preliminary report issued this month, it said its fourth quarter brought in its “best-ever quarterly sales of Android and Apple smartphones.” Corroborating healthy iPhone sales, Kantar Worldpanel Comtech, a research company, said that the iPhone was the top-selling smartphone in the United States over the fourth quarter. It estimated that the iPhone accounted for 51.2 percent of smartphone sales in the United States over the quarter; sales of Android phones in that time period remained flat with about 44 percent of the market. These numbers come contrary to a report last week from The Wall Street Journal, which said that Apple had cut orders of parts for the iPhone 5 from its manufacturers because of weaker-than-expected demand. However, some analysts said Apple might have cut down on orders for parts because it placed a large order last quarter to keep up with high demand, leaving some inventory left over for the coming quarter. Chetan Sharma, an independent mobile analyst, said in an interview that he did not find the reports about weak iPhone demand to be credible. “The iPhone is seeing significant competition from Samsung, but that doesn’t mean the demand for iPhone was waning,” Mr. Sharma said. “It just means there’s more pressure to produce a better iPhone next time around.”"

Topic.Title: I admit I bashed while I was long so I could add in the 480's. It was success

Message.Msg: I like to see a well written post like yours. I have traded and held Apple for the last 9 years. I too watch what young people want and buy. I have had great gains with this company but it has sometimes been painful. The iPhone reminds me of the Western Electric from Bell. Tough, reliable, worked forever; you just weren't looking for something different because it was that good. I am amused by the constant demands for more innovation when the existing products are so wonderful. Maybe you need to be a little older to appreciate the massive moves in communications technology over the past decade. The relentless bashing of late is not consistent with reality. Fortunately, the vast majority of people buying Apple products don't read the financial "journalism" so they don't know that Apple is gasping its last breath.

Topic.Title: serious options question

Message.Msg: The 600s are too far out. How much are you prepared to risk on this? The real money on your bullish view would be to do one or a combo of the following: (1) sell just OTM puts (feb1 or 16 exp) and buy puts deeper out (weeklies). Big net credit. You can take the net credit and then buy a ladder of calls from just out of the money calls to a few deep otm. You can also mess with the exp. The farther OTM will need Feb 16 at least (2) the other play you could make, is a claendar spread on the call side. Sell OTM expiring weeklies and buy Feb 16 calls at the same strike. Then IV doesnt necessarily hurt you and time value helps you. If the stock moves against you, you are a bit hedged. If it moves with you, you have to decide how you want to play (cover your short call, close your long call etc. -- the timing can be tricky, but you won;t lose money). You can do a calendar call spread and also do the put vertical spread I described at (1).

Message.Title: Verizon Iphone #'s show Apple is gaining share at the lower end.
Message.Msg: People don't get it. Apple is about Simplicity. In the US, they have no need for a more affordable phone. The big 3 have cell phone subsidies that make iPhone Classics like the 4 & 4S almost free to consumers, but Apple receives healthy payments. Apple will introduce a "Classic" phone is Asia first (that was hinted by Tim Cook) where subsidies do not exist and may not even bring to USA unless they phase out the iPhone 4 and replace a high margin product for them. Apple can now create excitement about Asia receiving a NEW iphone Classic FIRST when they announce the China Mobile deal this year. Shorts are Toast in the next 180 days. Why introduce in the USA when they own 63% share of Verizon Smart phones, 80% of AT &T and equally high numbers at Sprint. How much more share gain can be achieved? Those phones are FREE to consumers. The only thing CHEAP at Apple is the stock price. The illusion will become real and the more real it becomes...The more people will drive Apple to record highs.

Topic.Title: Verizon Sales - Same quarter last year (with an extra week of sales)

Message.Msg: BOOM! Remember, Tim Cook said after visiting with China Mobile and the Industry Info and Tech Minister recently, that "China is currently our second largest market. I believe it will become our first. I believe strongly that it will," Cook said that he believes China will become Apple’s most important market in the “not too distant future.” My opinion is that he wouldn't make a statement like that to be published in the Chinese media if he didn't have China Mobile in the bag, as it could compromise his bargaining position, but who knows. One thing we know by the 2 million Iphone5 sold in first three days of sales in China in December, is that Apple is getting some real traction there and that China and their growing, upwardly mobile consumer class should provide a nice growth for a while, especially if China Mobile comes aboard, and this is regardless of whether or not Apple comes out with some new whiz bang gadget that creates or expands a new market segment. This isn't advice or a suggestion to buy or sell any securities. As of this writing I am long apple related securities that I may choose to hold or sell at any time.

Topic.Title: .28 cents consensus?

Message.Msg: They have NEVER INCLUDED AG yet in quarterly earnings! They won't sniff .55 when they're only projected for $1.10+ for the YEAR. You do know that not a single event has an impact on Yahoo right? Every year its something whether its Michael Jacksons death, Patrick Swayze, both Olympics, 2 presidential elections...NONE have an impact. Yahoo's revenues are simply too broad, too International, and simply too large to be impacted. Google was very light on revenue tonight and revenue per-click is falling so the question becomes did Yahoo buy enough shares to offset that? Yahoo's operating income for the previous year was $840M and you aren't to far for the QUARTER! I don't get it...you make the same topic yesterday, I correct you, and you STILL believe what is WRONG. Head over to Investor Relations if you don't believe me as the last 4 quarters are there...99.9999% sure you won't find AG revenue in any of it.
